title: 114_hr3484
content: The Act titled "Los Angeles Homeless Veterans Leasing Act of 2016" authorizes certain leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may carry out leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for purposes of providing supportive housing to benefit veterans and their families. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may carry out leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for purposes of providing supportive housing, education, vocational training, and health promotion for veterans and their families. The Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus offers a range of services for veterans and their families, including health promotion, education, vocational training, peer activities, legal assistance, volunteerism, family support, and transportation. The Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus provides services such as health promotion, education, vocational training, legal assistance, volunteerism, family support, transportation, and leasing real property to The Regents of the University of California for up to 10 years. The Regents of the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) can lease real property from the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for up to 10 years if the lease aligns with the master plan, focuses on providing services to veterans, and includes an agreement to continue providing services during the lease term. The Regents at the Campus must provide additional services and support benefiting veterans and their families during the lease term. The Regents at the Campus must provide services that primarily benefit veterans and their families, including those who are severely disabled, women, aging, or homeless, through various activities related to medical, clinical, therapeutic, dietary, rehabilitative, legal, mental, spiritual, physical, recreational, research, and counseling needs. The Regents must provide services for veterans and their families, including those who are severely disabled, women, aging, or homeless, covering various needs such as rehabilitative, legal, mental, spiritual, physical, recreational, research, and counseling. The Regents must maintain records of the additional services provided and make them available to the Secretary. The Secretary must ensure that any land-sharing agreement at the Campus provides additional health-care resources to veterans and their families, excluding revenue generation for the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary must ensure that any land-sharing agreement at the Campus provides additional health-care resources to veterans and their families, excluding revenue generation for the Department of Veterans Affairs. Revenues from leases at the Campus are to be used exclusively for renovation and maintenance without fiscal year limitation. The Secretary may grant easements or rights-of-way on lands at the Campus to public transportation authorities for mass transit facilities under certain conditions. The Secretary may grant easements on lands at the Campus to public transportation authorities for mass transit facilities, including fixed guideway facilities and transportation centers. This includes granting rights to local or regional public transportation authorities and the State of California, County of Los Angeles, City of Los Angeles, or any agency or public utility company for various services. The Secretary may grant easements on lands at the Campus to public transportation authorities for mass transit facilities, including fixed guideway facilities and transportation centers. This includes granting rights to local or regional public transportation authorities and the State of California, County of Los Angeles, City of Los Angeles, or any agency or public utility company for providing public utilities. Improvements proposed under the easement or right-of-way shall be subject to appropriate terms and conditions, and any authorized easement or right-of-way shall be terminated upon abandonment. The Secretary may grant easements on lands at the Campus to public transportation authorities for mass transit facilities, subject to appropriate terms and conditions. Any authorized easement or right-of-way shall be terminated upon abandonment. The Secretary is prohibited from selling or conveying fee simple title to any real property or improvements at the Campus. The Secretary is prohibited from selling or conveying fee simple title to any real property or improvements at the Campus. Leases must be consistent with the approved master plan and comply with relevant laws. The Secretary may not enter into any lease or land-sharing agreement at the Campus if the Inspector General determines non-compliance with Federal laws relating to leases and land use, or significant mismanagement has occurred. The Secretary cannot enter into any lease or land-sharing agreement at the Campus unless in compliance with laws, and all recommendations from an audit report have been implemented. The Secretary must ensure that all recommendations from an audit report are implemented before entering into any lease or land-sharing agreement at the Campus. Additionally, leases must comply with federal laws related to environmental and historic preservation. The Secretary must establish a Community Veterans Engagement Board within 180 days to coordinate with the Department of Veterans Affairs for the Campus. The Board will identify community goals and provide advice to improve services for veterans, Armed Forces members, and their families. The Community Veterans Engagement Board will advise the Secretary on improving services for veterans, Armed Forces members, and their families. The Board will be comprised of members, with at least 50% being veterans, and the rest being family members, veteran advocates, service providers, or stakeholders. The Community Veterans Engagement Board will have members, with less than 50 percent being veterans, and the rest being family members, veteran advocates, service providers, or stakeholders. The Board will provide community opportunities for collaboration and focus on local issues identified by the community regarding health care, benefits, and memorial services at the Campus. The Community Veterans Engagement Board will focus on local issues identified by the community regarding health care, benefits, and memorial services at the Campus. The Secretary must notify relevant congressional committees and representatives about lease agreements at the Campus. The Secretary must notify relevant congressional committees and representatives about lease agreements at the Campus, renewals must be communicated at least 45 days in advance. Annual reports on lease agreements must be submitted to the committees. The Secretary must provide annual reports to congressional committees on lease agreements at the Campus, evaluating revenue management and land-sharing agreements. The Secretary must provide annual reports to congressional committees on lease agreements at the Campus, evaluating revenue management and land-sharing agreements. The Inspector General of the Department of Veterans Affairs must also provide reports every two and five years after the enactment of this Act. The Inspector General of the Department of Veterans Affairs must submit reports on all leases at the Campus to congressional committees every two and five years after the enactment of this Act. The Inspector General of the Department of Veterans Affairs must submit reports on all leases at the Campus to congressional committees every two and five years after the enactment of this Act, including an assessment of the Department's efforts to implement the master plan for the Campus. The Inspector General must submit reports on Campus leases to Congress, considering the most recent report by the Secretary. The Secretary has the authority to enter into agreements not inconsistent with this section. "Principally Benefit Veterans and Their Families" is defined. The Secretary has the authority to enter into agreements regarding the Campus that are authorized by law. The term "Principally Benefit Veterans and Their Families" is defined as services exclusively for veterans and their families or designed for their particular needs. Services provided exclusively for veterans and their families or designed for their particular needs, with any benefit to the general public being secondary. Excludes services that only generate revenue for the Department of Veterans Affairs. The curr_chunk discusses exclusions of services that only benefit the Department of Veterans Affairs financially. It also includes amendments related to the disposal of property and enhanced-use leases. The curr_chunk amends sections related to enhanced-use leases under the Los Angeles Homeless Veterans Leasing Act of 2016 in title 38, United States Code.
